title: Bed Bath & Beyond Is No Bargain
text:
Text size

We’re always on the lookout for bargains. But while Bed Bath & Beyond stores might offer some good ones, its stock doesn’t look like a bargain after soaring following the appointment of a new CEO.

It isn’t that Bed Bath & Beyond (BBBY) made a poor choice. This past Thursday, it announced that Target’s (TGT) chief merchandising officer, Mark Tritton, would take the helm. Hiring someone with Tritton’s expertise to oversee a turnaround effort is very good news. If nothing else, he has the skills to fix one of the chain’s biggest problems—its lack of distinctive products. Jefferies analyst Jonathan Matuszewski calls its assortment “commoditized” and suggests that Tritton’s background in private-label goods could go a long way toward remedying that.

Indeed, the stock soared 31%, to $12.98, in the two days after the Tritton announcement—and is up 75% since its August low. That climb began seemingly out of nothing. It started before reports, perhaps spurred by an activist’s involvement, that Goldman Sachs had been hired to lead an auction of some of its noncore units. And it began before a string of upgrades from analysts bullish about the possibilities if Bed Bath & Beyond finally hired a new CEO. That’s a long way of saying that the news might actually be reflected in the stock price.

Now comes the hard part.

Jefferies’ Matuszewski left his rating on the stock at Neutral, citing the “risk inherent in an early-stage transformation with no notable inflection in fundamentals yet.” He’s right about that. Same-store sales have dropped by more than 6% in the past two quarters, while revenue is expected to decline by 5.7%, to $11.35 billion, in fiscal 2020.

Then there’s the matter of pricing. For Bed Bath & Beyond to compete online with the likes of Amazon.com (AMZN), it needs to lower its prices. And that is exactly what it has been doing, according to Loop Capital analyst Anthony Chukumba. He compared prices on 50 goods and found that Bed Bath & Beyond’s were 8.6% higher than Amazon’s, though they’re cheaper if shoppers use one of the chain’s 20%-off coupons. That makes Bed Bath & Beyond more competitive, but probably isn’t good for its stock, Chukumba writes. “While we typically view more competitive pricing as a positive...we believe this will place pressure on BBBY’s gross margin,” he explains.

But perhaps the biggest reason for caution is that Bed Bath & Beyond isn’t Target. Wells Fargo analyst Zachary Fadem argues that shoppers go to the two stores for different reasons, and that Target never had Bed Bath & Beyond’s store-traffic problems. Throw in the potential margin issues that could come with more competitive pricing and greater online sales, and the stock looks like it might have gotten ahead of itself.

“With Bed Bath & Beyond shares up about 20% post-announcement, we see the market putting the cart before the horse,” Fadem writes. Though he raised his price target to $10, from $9, after Tritton’s appointment, Fadem reiterated his Underperform rating on the stock.

Sure, Bed Bath & Beyond’s shares are still cheap. They now trade at 6.8 times 12-month forward earnings, up from 3.9 times at their August low. We’re just not sure that is cheap enough.

Write to Ben Levisohn at Ben.Levisohn@barrons.com
description: New CEO Mark Tritton has the skills to refresh Bed Bath & Beyond’s merchandise. But the good news is now priced into the stock.
